channel.title: Wiretap on The Encryption Compendium
channel.description: Recent content in Wiretap on The Encryption Compendium

item.title: CALEA II: Risks of Wiretap Modifications to Endpoints
item.description: Authors: Adida, Ben and Anderson, Collin and Anton, Annie I. and Blaze, Matt and Dingledine, Roger and Felten, Edward W. and Green, Matthew D. and Halderman, J. Alex and Jefferson, David R. and Jennings, Cullen and Landau, Susan and Mitter, Navroop and Neumann, Peter G. and Rescorla, Eric and Schneider, Fred B. and Schneier, Bruce and Shacham, Hovav and Sherr, Micah and Wagner, David and Zimmermann, Philip Published: May 2013

item.title: Wiretapping and Cryptography Today
item.description: Authors: Blaze, Matt Published: July 2011 URL: https://web.archive.org/web/20110715210433/http://www.crypto.com/blog/wiretap2010 Abstract: This blog post from Matt Blaze examines the 2011 Wiretap report and argues that encryption has done little to hinder law enforcement. The blog post points out that despite the increased prevalence of encryption, few wiretap searches by law enforcement even encountered encryption, and never did it interfere with the investigation. The proposes that with the increased prevalence of encryption, law enforcement methods have adapted.
